addIdeas.title: AI-as-foil: compare, correct, and cite
addIdeas.deliverable: Short critique + corrected explanation with citations
steps: Generate an explanation or solution using your writing/productivity AI tool.
Have students identify at least 3 issues: missing nuance, unsupported claims, bias, or oversimplification.
Students correct the output using course materials and scholarly sources; add citations.
Optional: students write a reflection on what the AI did well/poorly and what they learned.

explain: Use AI output as a foil to practice evaluation, correction, and citation.

addIdeas.title: Inquiry cycle: hypothesis → evidence → revision
steps: Use AI to propose 3 plausible hypotheses or interpretations related to the topic.
Students design an evidence-gathering plan (articles, data, primary sources).
Students test AI hypotheses against evidence; keep a discrepancy log.
Submit a revised hypothesis and a brief methods/evidence justification.

explain: Inquiry-based activity where AI is used to generate hypotheses, then evidence revises.

addIdeas.title: Rubric calibration workshop
steps: Draft or revise a rubric aligned to learning outcomes (start from your existing rubric if available).
Use AI to generate 2–3 sample responses (clearly labeled as synthetic) at different quality levels.
In class, students apply the rubric to samples; compare results and refine rubric language.
Finalize rubric + brief rationale on how criteria support learning objectives.

explain: Rubric and exemplar calibration to align outcomes and assessment clarity.

addIdeas.title: Source map + citation chain assignment
steps: Use Semantic Scholar or ResearchRabbit to build a citation network from 1 seed article.
Select 6 sources representing 3 different methods or perspectives.
Summarize each source (claim + evidence + limitation) and link it in the map.
Write a mini-synthesis explaining how the field ‘talks to itself’ (where evidence converges/diverges).

explain: Map literature via citation chaining to support synthesis and gap-finding.

addIdeas.title: AI policy micro-brief (course or lab)
addIdeas.deliverable: One-page AI use policy + transparency statement
steps: Identify 3 risks and 3 opportunities of AI use in your course or lab context.
Draft an AI use policy (allowed / conditional / prohibited) with examples.
Create a transparency statement template students can attach to work.
Peer review in pairs for clarity, fairness, and enforceability.

explain: Draft a context-aware AI policy with transparency statements and peer review.

addIdeas.title: Rapid literature triage + evidence table
addIdeas.deliverable: Evidence table + ‘what we know / don’t know’ memo
steps: Use discovery tools to find 10–15 candidate sources; screen abstracts with inclusion/exclusion criteria.
Extract claims, methods, samples, and limitations into an evidence table.
Use a writing tool to propose themes; verify by re-checking sources.
Draft a memo: 5 strongest findings, 3 gaps, 2 promising future directions.

explain: Evidence-table workflow for rigorous literature review triage and synthesis.

addIdeas.title: Claim-checking with citation context
steps: List 5 key claims you intend to make (or that AI suggested).
Use Scite to check how core sources are cited (supporting/contrasting).
Revise claims with qualifiers and stronger evidence where needed.
Document changes in an audit log (before/after + citations).

explain: Use citation context to tighten claims and document revisions.

addIdeas.title: Data narrative + visualization storyboard
steps: Use Julius/Quadratic to explore your dataset and generate candidate visualizations.
Select 2–3 visuals that answer a coherent question (avoid ‘chart dumping’).
Write captions: what the chart shows, what it doesn’t, and what assumptions it rests on.
Create a storyboard that connects visuals into an argument with limitations and next steps.

explain: Turn analysis into interpretable visuals + narrative with limitations.

addIdeas.title: Grant/IRB prewriting assistant
steps: Use a writing tool to draft specific aims and expected contributions.
Identify ethical/privacy risks (data, consent, bias) and propose mitigations.
Create a simple timeline and resource plan; flag dependencies.
Have a colleague or stakeholder review for feasibility and clarity.

explain: Structured prewriting for grant/IRB with risk/mitigation framing.

addIdeas.title: Program-level AI readiness checklist
steps: Identify stakeholders (faculty, students, IT, library, compliance).
Draft a checklist for responsible AI use (privacy, integrity, accessibility, documentation).
Create a communication plan for rollout: FAQs, examples, and escalation paths.
Pilot with a small group; collect feedback and revise.

explain: Program-level checklist + comms plan for responsible AI adoption.

addIdeas.title: Health/Nursing: Quick (Apply) activity using your toolkit
steps: Define a concrete question within your discipline (scope it to what you can check).
If working with clinical scenarios, treat AI outputs as hypothetical: validate against clinical guidelines and local standards; avoid PHI.
Use discovery/lit tools to gather credible sources or evidence; keep a citations list.
Use a writing tool to draft an output; then verify key claims against the sources.
Add a short transparency note: what AI did, what you checked, and what limitations remain.

explain: Discipline-targeted workflow emphasizing evidence and transparency.

addIdeas.title: Concept check: AI-generated quiz + correction
steps: Use AI to generate 5 concept-check questions on the topic (label as AI-generated).
Students answer; then compare with an instructor-provided or source-backed key.
Students correct any AI errors and add a citation for each corrected point.

explain: Bloom-aligned activity template.

addIdeas.title: Concept check: AI-generated quiz + correction
steps: Use AI to generate 5 concept-check questions on the topic (label as AI-generated).
Students answer; then compare with an instructor-provided or source-backed key.
Students correct any AI errors and add a citation for each corrected point.

explain: Bloom-aligned activity template.

addIdeas.title: Concept check: AI-generated quiz + correction
steps: Use AI to generate 5 concept-check questions on the topic (label as AI-generated).
Students answer; then compare with an instructor-provided or source-backed key.
Students correct any AI errors and add a citation for each corrected point.

explain: Bloom-aligned activity template.

addIdeas.title: Worked example remix
steps: Ask AI for a worked example on the topic.
Students identify the method/steps and apply them to a new variant you provide.
Students annotate where AI’s method works and where it breaks (edge cases).

explain: Bloom-aligned activity template.

addIdeas.title: Worked example remix
steps: Ask AI for a worked example on the topic.
Students identify the method/steps and apply them to a new variant you provide.
Students annotate where AI’s method works and where it breaks (edge cases).

explain: Bloom-aligned activity template.

addIdeas.title: Worked example remix
steps: Ask AI for a worked example on the topic.
Students identify the method/steps and apply them to a new variant you provide.
Students annotate where AI’s method works and where it breaks (edge cases).

explain: Bloom-aligned activity template.

addIdeas.title: Methodology teardown
steps: Use AI to summarize a study or method (you provide the paper).
Students map: research question → method → evidence → inference chain.
Students identify confounds/limitations and propose improvements.

explain: Bloom-aligned activity template.

addIdeas.title: Methodology teardown
steps: Use AI to summarize a study or method (you provide the paper).
Students map: research question → method → evidence → inference chain.
Students identify confounds/limitations and propose improvements.

explain: Bloom-aligned activity template.

addIdeas.title: Methodology teardown
steps: Use AI to summarize a study or method (you provide the paper).
Students map: research question → method → evidence → inference chain.
Students identify confounds/limitations and propose improvements.

explain: Bloom-aligned activity template.

addIdeas.title: Argument audit + claim-strength ladder
steps: Draft an argument (or have AI draft) with 6 claims.
Students rank claims by evidential strength (with citations).
Students rewrite 2 weak claims into stronger, properly qualified claims.

explain: Bloom-aligned activity template.

addIdeas.title: Argument audit + claim-strength ladder
steps: Draft an argument (or have AI draft) with 6 claims.
Students rank claims by evidential strength (with citations).
Students rewrite 2 weak claims into stronger, properly qualified claims.

explain: Bloom-aligned activity template.

addIdeas.title: Argument audit + claim-strength ladder
steps: Draft an argument (or have AI draft) with 6 claims.
Students rank claims by evidential strength (with citations).
Students rewrite 2 weak claims into stronger, properly qualified claims.

explain: Bloom-aligned activity template.

addIdeas.title: Design sprint: assignment or research plan
steps: Use AI to propose 3 designs (assignment formats or study designs).
Students select one and produce a design brief: objectives, criteria, risks.
Peer review and revise; include an AI-transparency statement.

explain: Bloom-aligned activity template.

addIdeas.title: Design sprint: assignment or research plan
steps: Use AI to propose 3 designs (assignment formats or study designs).
Students select one and produce a design brief: objectives, criteria, risks.
Peer review and revise; include an AI-transparency statement.

explain: Bloom-aligned activity template.

addIdeas.title: Design sprint: assignment or research plan
steps: Use AI to propose 3 designs (assignment formats or study designs).
Students select one and produce a design brief: objectives, criteria, risks.
Peer review and revise; include an AI-transparency statement.

explain: Bloom-aligned activity template.

addIdeas.title: Online discussion: AI as a ‘first post’ to critique
steps: AI generates a ‘first post’ stance on the topic (clearly labeled).
Students respond by correcting, expanding, and citing course readings.
Students post a rebuttal that addresses counterarguments and evidence.

addIdeas.title: Online discussion: AI as a ‘first post’ to critique
steps: AI generates a ‘first post’ stance on the topic (clearly labeled).
Students respond by correcting, expanding, and citing course readings.
Students post a rebuttal that addresses counterarguments and evidence.

addIdeas.title: In-class jigsaw: AI-generated perspectives
steps: AI generates 4 perspectives on the topic.
Groups each fact-check one perspective using library sources.
Class synthesizes: what holds, what fails, and what’s missing.

addIdeas.title: In-class jigsaw: AI-generated perspectives
steps: AI generates 4 perspectives on the topic.
Groups each fact-check one perspective using library sources.
Class synthesizes: what holds, what fails, and what’s missing.

addIdeas.title: Hybrid workflow: prep with AI, validate in class
steps: Students use AI pre-class to generate questions and predicted misconceptions.
In class, groups validate with readings/data and revise questions.
Submit a revised ‘best questions’ set with citations.

addIdeas.title: Hybrid workflow: prep with AI, validate in class
steps: Students use AI pre-class to generate questions and predicted misconceptions.
In class, groups validate with readings/data and revise questions.
Submit a revised ‘best questions’ set with citations.

addIdeas.title: HyFlex parallel activity: shared evidence table
steps: AI suggests candidate sources and claims; students must verify sources.
Both modalities contribute to a shared evidence table (claims, evidence, limitation).
Students write a reflection on reliability and verification.

addIdeas.title: HyFlex parallel activity: shared evidence table
steps: AI suggests candidate sources and claims; students must verify sources.
Both modalities contribute to a shared evidence table (claims, evidence, limitation).
Students write a reflection on reliability and verification.

addIdeas.title: Image prompt storyboard for instruction/outreach
steps: Draft a storyboard (3 frames) for an instructional concept or outreach message (no real people).
Generate images with your image tool; iterate prompts for clarity and bias reduction.
Write alt-text for each image and a note about what was AI-generated and how it can be reused.

addIdeas.title: Audio cleanup for lecture capture / interview clarity
steps: Use an audio cleanup tool to reduce noise and improve clarity.
Generate or correct a transcript; spot-check accuracy against the audio.
Add a brief accessibility statement about transcription accuracy and limitations.

addIdeas.title: Micro-clip for outreach (non-realistic characters)
steps: Write a short script for a micro-clip (avoid realistic human likeness).
Generate a clip using a video tool; keep it short and clearly stylized.
Add a disclosure caption and verify that any music/assets are properly licensed.

addIdeas.title: Safety check: privacy, student data, and permissions
steps: Identify whether any student data, grades, or identifiable info is involved.
If yes, avoid pasting sensitive data into third-party tools; use approved systems.
Write a short mitigation plan (redaction, consent, secure storage, alternatives).

explain: Ethics-first guardrail when topic indicates risk.

addIdeas.title: Safety check: bias and representation audit
steps: Scan outputs for stereotypes, missing perspectives, or biased language.
Cross-check with credible sources representing impacted communities.
Revise prompts/outputs and document what changed and why.

explain: Ethics-first guardrail when topic indicates risk.

addIdeas.title: Safety check: copyright and attribution
steps: Confirm whether tool outputs can be reused and under what terms.
Add attribution where required; avoid copying protected text/media without permission.
Include a transparency note describing AI assistance and what was original.

explain: Ethics-first guardrail when topic indicates risk.

addIdeas.title: Peer-review studio with AI-assisted revision questions
steps: Students submit a draft + 3 questions they want feedback on.
AI generates 5 revision prompts (clarity, evidence, structure) to guide peer review.
Peers respond using rubric criteria; students write a revision plan with cited evidence needs.
Optional: require a transparency statement describing AI usage.

addIdeas.title: Iterative portfolio with AI-supported reflection checkpoints
steps: Define portfolio criteria and checkpoints (what ‘good’ looks like).
At each checkpoint, use AI to generate reflective questions; answer with evidence from your work.
Use feedback (human + AI prompts) to revise; keep a change log.
Submit final synthesis describing growth, limitations, and next steps.

addIdeas.title: Misinformation lab: trace claims across sources
addIdeas.deliverable: Claim trace report + source credibility rubric
steps: Pick one circulating claim and locate 5 sources that repeat it.
Use tools to find original evidence (or lack thereof) and how citations mutate.
Build a credibility rubric; rate each source and justify with evidence.
Write a short ‘what to do next’ guidance note for non-experts.
